question: Question_01_(i)
statement:
Calculate the derivative $\displaystyle f'(x)$ if

\begin{align*}f(x)=\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt.\end{align*}
sols:
Using the fundamental theorem of calculus, we have

\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx}\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt \\
&= \frac{d}{dx}\left( \int_x^{0} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt +  \int_{0}^{e^{x}} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt\right)\\
&= \frac{d}{dx}\left( -\int_{0}^{x} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt +  \int_{0}^{e^{x}} \sqrt{\cos{t}}\, dt\right)\\
&=  - \sqrt{\cos{x}} +  e^{x} \sqrt{\cos{e^{x}}}\end{align*}

where in the last equality on the right most sum, we used the chain rule
to compute the derivative. This completes the question.
hints: Use the fundamental theorem of calculus.

The integral given in this problem has a function of x in both bounds
(top and bottom). You can split the integral into two parts to obtain
the form in the previous hint.
